original_title: Vital step in modernizing Sri Lanka’s labour legislation
original_body_lines: A high-level committee appointed by the Cabinet to review and amend Sri Lanka’s proposed Labour Act convened for the first time recently at the Ministry of Labour. The move marks a significant step towards modernizing labour legislation to address the evolving needs of the workforce across the state, semi-government and private sectors.

The meeting was chaired by S. M. Piyathissa, Secretary to the Ministry of Labour, with the participation of Labour Minister Dr. Anil Jayantha Fernando. The committee comprises top legal professionals, human resource and finance experts, Labour Commissioner General Nadika Watalyadda, and Additional Secretary (Development) Muditha Padmajay.
Deputy Minister of Labour Mahinda Jayasinghe stressed the importance of the initiative, stating:

“This reform process is critical to ensure Sri Lanka’s labour laws meet global standards while remaining business-friendly. Our aim is to create a framework that safeguards workers’ rights, improves productivity and enhances investor confidence in the Sri Lankan economy.”

The government stressed that the amendments will align with International Labour Organization (ILO) conventions and be designed to reflect modern economic realities. The updated legal framework is also expected to strengthen tripartite relations between government, employers and employees, laying the groundwork for greater industrial stability.

According to ministry officials, the committee is expected to complete its review and prepare a draft set of recommendations within the next three to six months. The government aims to table the revised Labour Act in Parliament before the end of the year, with stakeholder consultations—including trade unions, employer federations and business chambers—scheduled to take place during the drafting process.

Business leaders stressed that predictable timelines and transparent consultations will be critical for ensuring broad acceptance of the reforms, which are expected to play a pivotal role in attracting foreign direct investment and boosting Sri Lanka’s competitiveness in global markets.
